snippet.textDisplay: I always considered Lost Odyssey to be the last true Final Fantasy game.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you're talking about the classic J-RPG genre then yes, this would be considered the final classic J-RPG.
 Kinda sad when you think about.

I'm just glad to have played such an amazing game and all future ones to come!
snippet.textOriginal:
If you're talking about the classic J-RPG genre then yes, this would be considered the final classic J-RPG.
 Kinda sad when you think about.

I'm just glad to have played such an amazing game and all future ones to come!

snippet.textDisplay: Traditional turn based combat, epic story, massive world, and music by Nobuo Uematsu? Not to mention it was directed by Sakaguchi! Yup, it's a Final Fantasy game in every way but the title, and one of the best JRPGs ever.
snippet.textOriginal: Traditional turn based combat, epic story, massive world, and music by Nobuo Uematsu? Not to mention it was directed by Sakaguchi! Yup, it's a Final Fantasy game in every way but the title, and one of the best JRPGs ever.

snippet.textDisplay:
Everything about this game rang "Ah...the good ol' days!" I loved it so much that I actually refused to beat it because I hate it when good things come to an end. It's been years now since I've last played it.
Amazing graphics. Epic cinematic scenes. Beautiful music. Action packed and dramatic story. Sad, heart tugging stories of Kaim's past.
I'm definitely going to play it again and beat it this time.
snippet.textOriginal:
Everything about this game rang "Ah...the good ol' days!" I loved it so much that I actually refused to beat it because I hate it when good things come to an end. It's been years now since I've last played it.
Amazing graphics. Epic cinematic scenes. Beautiful music. Action packed and dramatic story. Sad, heart tugging stories of Kaim's past.
I'm definitely going to play it again and beat it this time.

snippet.textDisplay: Isn't he ^^ I really am so glad Nobou left Square Enix to start his own music company, to create music for all sorts of games. Yes thankfully he does still create music for Square Enix, though not so much lately it seems, but Nobou's music in Lost Odyssey is some of the best music I've ever had the pleasure of hearing, not just exclusive to gaming
snippet.textOriginal: Isn't he ^^ I really am so glad Nobou left Square Enix to start his own music company, to create music for all sorts of games. Yes thankfully he does still create music for Square Enix, though not so much lately it seems, but Nobou's music in Lost Odyssey is some of the best music I've ever had the pleasure of hearing, not just exclusive to gaming

snippet.textDisplay: I couldn't agree more. I also didn't realize until I played this how much I missed out on the classic battle system, I never got to play a game with a battle style like this before. Even so this was completely different. The stunning graphics during each battle, yet keeping it classic, but having new and improved features. But the story and characters is what makes this among my favorite games, the gameplay really was a huge bonus I wasn't expecting
snippet.textOriginal: I couldn't agree more. I also didn't realize until I played this how much I missed out on the classic battle system, I never got to play a game with a battle style like this before. Even so this was completely different. The stunning graphics during each battle, yet keeping it classic, but having new and improved features. But the story and characters is what makes this among my favorite games, the gameplay really was a huge bonus I wasn't expecting

snippet.textDisplay: Lost Odyssey is far from a masterpiece of the RPG genre, and even the soundtrack isn't terribly memorable (by Uematsu's standards anyway)... and yet, I can't help loving it. It's obvious that a lot of love went into making this game. It's one of only two games (the other being Crisis Core) to bring me to tears, and the ONLY game to make me cry more than once.
snippet.textOriginal: Lost Odyssey is far from a masterpiece of the RPG genre, and even the soundtrack isn't terribly memorable (by Uematsu's standards anyway)... and yet, I can't help loving it. It's obvious that a lot of love went into making this game. It's one of only two games (the other being Crisis Core) to bring me to tears, and the ONLY game to make me cry more than once.

snippet.textDisplay: To people complaining about the load times, install the game to your HDD. It's a big file and if you only have a 20GB drive you'll probably only manage one disk at a time but it makes a massive difference.

snippet.textDisplay:
The words on the gravestone were chosen by Greo himself.

He explained his choice to Kaim this way: "I would say the words to each new pair of shoes before I handed them to the customer. I always said them to the customer, too. I never once had the experience, though, of someone saying the words to me."

"May your journey be a good one!"

These were the words the old man always spoke. Coming from his mouth they could be brusque, but they were always charged with feeling.
snippet.textOriginal:
The words on the gravestone were chosen by Greo himself.

He explained his choice to Kaim this way: "I would say the words to each new pair of shoes before I handed them to the customer. I always said them to the customer, too. I never once had the experience, though, of someone saying the words to me."

"May your journey be a good one!"

These were the words the old man always spoke. Coming from his mouth they could be brusque, but they were always charged with feeling.

snippet.textDisplay: Yeah, I bought this when it first came out, it's gorgeous, and the music is great.  I guess there aren't many of us who miss the classic battle system, I was so happy when I played it and it wasn't a crazy-dumb "revolutionary" battle system.  Also, it let you have 5 party members, which was awesome, like old times.
snippet.textOriginal: Yeah, I bought this when it first came out, it's gorgeous, and the music is great.  I guess there aren't many of us who miss the classic battle system, I was so happy when I played it and it wasn't a crazy-dumb "revolutionary" battle system.  Also, it let you have 5 party members, which was awesome, like old times.

snippet.textDisplay: the load times don't seem much worse (if at all) than most other RPGs on CD/DVD to me, and the game makes FFX look slow & grindy in comparison IMO (although you'd prolly disagree with that :p).  It's a very solid game and the reviews really didn't do it justice.

snippet.textDisplay: Nobuo Uematsu definitely hasn't lost it. I've just started playing this game and this music directly hit me. Invoking emotion like this in a song takes a lot of talent, my eyes sometimes get misty when I hear it in the game (especially in the dreams) because it's often during a beautifully sad scene.
